title-group.article-title: Understanding the Relationships Between Commitment and Voice
title-group.subtitle: Hypotheses, Empirical Evidence, and Directions for Future Research

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Sharon E. Beatty (PhD, University of Oregon) is the Reese Phifer professor of marketing and marketing doctoral coordinator at The University of Alabama. Her research focuses on shopping and service relationship issues. She has published in journals such as Journal of Marketing Research, Journal of Consumer Research, Journal of Retailing, Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, and Journal of Service Research. She is on five editorial boards, such as Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, Journal of Retailing, and Journal of Service Research and on the senior advisory board of Journal of Marketing Theory and Practice.

Kristy E. Reynolds (PhD, University of Alabama) is the Bruno Professor of marketing at The University of Alabama. Her primary research focus lies in the areas of shopping and patronage behavior. Her research has been published in such journals as Journal of Marketing, Journal of Retailing, Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, Journal of Business Research, Journal of Service Research, Psychology & Marketing, Journal of Marketing Theory and Practice, and the Journal of Personal Selling & Sales Management. She is also on the editorial review boards for Journal of Retailing, Journal of Business Research, and the Journal of Service Research.

Stephanie M. Noble (PhD, UMass-Amherst) is an associate professor of marketing at the University of Tennessee. Her primary research interests include business-to-customer relationship marketing issues in retailing and service contexts. She has published in several journals including the MIT Sloan Management Review, Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, Journal of Retailing, Journal of Business Research, Journal of Advertising, Business Horizons, and several others. Dr. Noble has also provided consulting services for several leading companies including Viking Corporation, Hollywood Casino and Resorts, Houston Aeros, Laguna Tools, Food Lion, and Ruth’s Chris Steakhouse to name a few.

Mary P. Harrison (PhD, University of Alabama) is an assistant professor of marketing at Birmingham-Southern College. Her research interests include service relationship issues and consumer behavior in service and retailing contexts. She has published in the Journal of Business Research and the Journal of Marketing Theory and Practice.

abstract.p: This study aims to explicate why customers stay in service relationships, while additionally examining how different forms of commitment to these relationships affect customers' voice, both within and outside of the relationship. Based on qualitative interviews and an extensive literature review, we provide and test a framework linking staying reasons to commitment to voice utilizing a survey of 685 online panelists in committed service relationships. Our results illustrate the differential effects of staying reasons on commitment and commitment on voice. Social balance theory, social influence theory, and escalation of commitment provide important theoretical bases for why individuals stay. We examine a number of unexamined or underexplored gaps in the literature, finding seven notable links relative to staying reasons and commitment (relational benefits and resistance to change to calculative commitment; subjective norms and sunk costs to affective commitment; procedural switching costs, avoidance of conflict, and resistance to change to normative commitment). Additionally, a number of less explored, as well as previously studied, findings between commitments and voice are noted, including the strong negative impacts of calculative commitment and silent endurance on voice. This suggests the importance of the service provider not locking the customer in too tightly.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Understanding what drives consumers to stay in relationships with service providers is of critical importance to marketers (cf. Morgan and Hunt 1994), with Bolton, Lemon, and Verhoef (2004, p.287) arguing for the need to understand the “key drivers” of relationships better. We call the key drivers for staying in relationships “staying reasons.” Unfortunately, staying reasons have only received limited attention in the literature (cf. Colgate et al. 2007), although marketers consider retention of customers to be the holy grail in marketing (Reichheld 1993; Sewall and Brown 2002).

A central construct in understanding relationships is customer commitment. Bansal, Irving, and Taylor (2004) argued for the inclusion of commitment in the study of service provider switching. However, here we argue that commitment to the service provider, representing relational continuity between the parties, holds even greater promise in studying why individuals stay with service providers, but a comprehensive framework assessing the relationship between two constructs has not been forthcoming.

Further, in line with a call to study the effects of commitment on important discretionary behaviors (Bansal, Irving, and Taylor 2004), we draw on Hirschman’s (1970) ideas on voice. We address three voice elements—positive and negative word of mouth (PWOM and NWOM) to others, which can have a powerful impact on the sales and profitability of the company, and communication (or lack of) with the firm (a critical component of the consumers' interaction with the firm).

We use the three-component commitment model to connect the two constructs (staying reasons and voice) in an overarching framework (see Figure 1 ). This framework is articulated below and the model empirically tested on a group of consumers in committed relationships with service providers.

sec.title: Overview of Conceptual Framework
sec.p: While much of the research on commitment treats it as a global concept, researchers in marketing increasingly turn to the three-component view of commitment from organizational behavior (e.g., Meyer and Allen 1997) to understand committed customer-firm relationships better. This perspective includes three types of commitment—affective, normative, and calculative.

Affective commitment addresses the idea of individuals “wanting” to stay. This is the traditional view of commitment and relates to dedication-based factors (cf. Morgan and Hunt 1994). Calculative commitment involves individuals feeling that they “have” to stay, for example, perhaps they have a contract, perceive high switching costs, or feel there are no reasonable alternatives available. They are locked in (i.e., constraint based). Finally, normative commitm ent involves individuals feeling that they “should” stay in a relationship due to a moral or personal obligation, that is, based on social pressure. Normative commitment is the most misunderstood component and it is not clear when or how its staying reasons are dedication based versus constraint based (Meyer, Allen, and Smith 1993). While commitment reflects a motivation or willingness to stay with a service provider (regardless of the reasons why), the dominant commitment type (or types) are often the primary drivers of behaviors toward the provider (cf. Herscovitch and Meyer 2002).

Clearly, commitment, regardless of type, is the “glue” that keeps people in relationships, even in the possible face of dissatisfaction (cf. Han, Kwortnik, and Wang 2008), with higher repurchase intentions clearly related to commitment (Jones, Dacin, and Taylor 2011). Thus, commitment perfectly represents the state that consumers are in when they decide to stay in a relationship. They may stay for positive and/or negative staying reasons (which are defined as the reasons why someone stays in a relationship), but they are in a committed relationship. Researchers note the importance of understanding more about the antecedents and consequences of commitment components (cf. Bansal, Irving, and Taylor 2004; Geyskens et al. 1996; Jones et al. 2007). Thus, the first goal here is to identify and study the differential effects of staying reasons on commitment components.

Based on qualitative work and the existing literature, we identify four categories of staying reasons, with several involving two subdimensions, producing six staying reasons of interest: relational benefits, two types of switching barriers (sunk costs and procedural switching costs), subjective norms, and two personality variables (avoidance of conflict and resistance to change).

The first two dimensions, relational benefits and switching barriers, are similar to the two overarching staying dimensions identified by Colgate and his colleagues in his study of why customers decide to stay after a serious consideration to leave (Colgate et al. 2007). These include affirmatory factors and switching barriers and represent the positive (dedication-based) factors and negative (constraint-based) factors, respectively. The literature also supports the switching barrier subdimensions revealed in our qualitative work—sunk costs and procedural switching costs (Jones et al. 2007; Jones, Mothersbaugh, and Beatty 2002). Relational benefits are the positive effects of maintaining a relationship. Sunk costs (also known as relationship-specific investments) involve perceptions of investments of time, money, and/or energy put into the relationship over time (Bendapudi and Berry 1997; Rusbult 1980), while procedural switching costs involve perceptions of the costs involved to locate and move to a new provider (Jones et al. 2007).

The other factors, subjective norms and personality variables, have received less research attention relative to this area of research. Subjective norms refer to a person’s perceptions that important people think s/he should or should not engage in a particular action or hold a particular attitude (Fishbein and Ajzen 1980). They have received some attention as an antecedent to normative commitment (cf. Bansal, Irving, and Taylor 2004), while researchers have not linked the two personality variables, avoidance of conflict and resistance to change, to commitment. However, our interviews suggested the viability of these relationships. Avoidance of conflict is an attempt to protect the self from conflict, disapproval, and negative attention (Brock 1999), while resistance to change involves preferring the status quo and not wishing to change (Diamond 2008).

A second goal of this paper is to examine how commitment components affect a customer’s voice, that is, verbal expressions to the company or others. We identify three subcomponents of voice here—PWOM, NWOM, and silent endurance. In Hirschman’s (1970) theory of exit, voice, and loyalty an individual who experiences dissatisfaction with an organization (in our case, a service provider) has two options: exit (which our sample has ruled out) or voice, with voice defined as an attempt to express “dissatisfaction directly to management” or through “a general protest addressed to anyone who cares to listen” (p. 4). Thus, his view of voice deals with either the individual engaging with the organization for improvement or letting others know about the negative experience (i.e., NWOM). Further, he says that some individuals stay, hoping that things will improve, noting that they may “suffer in silence” (p. 38). We call this idea silent endurance, noting that often individuals stay because they feel that they can neither exit nor effectively voice complaints or concerns (i.e., a lack of voice). Finally, we also identify PWOM, which involves telling others good things about a firm, as the third voice component of interest here.

Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder (2007) studied complaining (variable included complaining to the firm and others) and PWOM relative to all commitments in a bank setting, while others (Fullerton 2011; Jones et al. 2007; Verhoef, Franses, and Hoekstra 2002) connect NWOM and PWOM to affective and calculative commitment. However, no effort connects all commitment components to all voice components in a cross-industry study. Thus, by studying the staying reasons producing commitment and the commitment antecedents of voice, we provide a comprehensive view of commitment and voice.

Toward these goals, we first conduct and analyze 22 depth interviews on the topic. Next, based on the qualitative findings, a literature review, and pretesting, we develop and test our model. Besides developing a comprehensive framework of staying reasons, commitment components, and voice elements, our findings illustrate the differential effects of staying reasons on commitment types and commitments on voice. Social balance theory, social influence theory, and escalation of commitment provide the important theoretical bases for reasons why individuals stay in relationships.

sec.title: Relational benefits→commitment
sec.p:
All three benefits link to affective commitment (see Table 1 for a sampling of these studies), based on reciprocity and social exchange theory (Blau 1964), with this established connection shown in the first hypothesis. On the other hand, researchers pay less attention to the potential linkages between relational benefits and the other commitments. However, we also anticipate a positive relationship between benefits and normative commitment. The logic of this link, peripherally studied relative to personal relationships (Barksdale, Johnson and Suh 1997), also draws from the reciprocity and social exchange (Blau 1964) paradigms. In social exchange theory, the exchange of resources tends to produce a sense of obligation by the recipient to reciprocate in kind (Eisenberger et al. 1997; Susskind, Kacmar, and Borchgrevink 2003).
Hypothesis 1ben: Relational benefits are positively associated with affective commitment.
Hypothesis 2ben: Relational benefits are positively associated with normative commitment.
However, the more benefits an individual feels s/he receives in a relationship the less s/he may feel locked into the relationship and will be less likely to feel like a hostage in a relationship (Verhoef, Franses, and Hoekstra 2002). Predictions and findings on this linkage are not consistent. Han, Kwortnik, and Wang (2008) find a positive relationship between commercial friendship (similar to social benefits) and calculative commitment (with their definition focusing on costs vs. benefits, however), while Geyskens et al. (1996) find a negative relationship between trust (similar to confidence benefits) and calculative commitment, in concert with our hypothesis.
Hypothesis 3ben: Relational benefits are negatively associated with calculative commitment.

sec.title: Subjective norms→commitment
sec.p:
Another important reason to stay in a relationship is due to strong subjective norms ( snorm ). When one feels pressure to do or not do something, the feeling to comply is strong (partially due to reciprocity regarding someone cared about or social pressure). The feeling to comply with others' wishes may produce affective commitment due to internationalization of the information or identification with the source (Bearden and Etzel 1982). Variables similar to subjective norms, such as organizational support (Rousseau and Aubé 2010; Vandenberghe, Bentein, and Stinglhamber 2004), have been linked to affective commitment, although the relationship per se has not been studied
Hypothesis 1snorm : Subjective norms are positively associated with affective commitment.
Alternatively, an individual may stay in the relationship because it is the right thing to do, due to normative social influence (Bearden and Etzel 1982). This desire to please or to “not displease” others can produce higher normative commitment. Finally, in some cases, individuals may feel so compelled by friends or family to comply with their wishes that they stay because they feel they need to stay, linking subjective norms to calculative commitment. Bansal, Irving, and Taylor (2004) find a strong link between subjective norms and normative commitment, while researchers have not linked subjective norms to calculative commitment.
Hypothesis 2snorm : Subjective norms are positively associated with normative commitment.
Hypothesis 3snorm
: Subjective norms are positively associated with calculative commitment.

sec.title: Switching barriers→commitments
sec.p:
Further, sunk costs should also produce a sense of obligation to stay in the relationship (i.e., normative commitment), following from a need or desire to reciprocate (Blau 1964), as well as due to an escalation-to-commitment effect (Bobocel and Meyer 1994). Meyer et al. (2002) suggest that organizational investments should relate positively to normative commitment, but note that this linkage lacked enough study to include in their meta-analysis.
Hypothesis 1sunk : Sunk costs are positively associated with affective commitment.
Hypothesis 2sunk : Sunk costs are positively associated with normative commitment.
Hypothesis 3sunk : Sunk costs are positively associated with calculative commitment.
Procedural switching costs ( pswitch ) suggest that consumers may feel that it is too much trouble, too costly, or too much effort to switch. Thus, we predict a null relationship between procedural switching costs and affective commitment because of the constraint nature of procedural switching costs and the dedication nature of affective commitment. On the other hand, Jones et al. (2007) argue that procedural switching costs make customers feel like “hostages” in the relationship (Sharma and Patterson 2000, p. 484), producing an expected positive relationship between procedural switching costs and calculative commitment.
Hypothesis 1pswitch : Procedural switching costs are not related to affective commitment.
Hypothesis 2pswitch : Procedural switching costs are positively associated with normative commitment.
Finally, the relationship between procedural switching costs and normative commitment is less clear. However, based on escalation of commitment (Bobocel and Meyer 1994), individuals with perceptions of high effort to switch (Meyer and Parfyonova 2010) may self-justify their staying behavior (Bendapudi and Berry 1997), believing they are staying out of a sense of duty.
Hypothesis 3pswitch : Procedural switching costs are positively associated with calculative commitment.

sec.title: Personality factors→commitment
sec.p:
While personality is seldom linked to commitment (for exceptions, see Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder 2007; Odekerken-Schröder, DeWulf, and Schumacher 2003; Vazquez-Carrasco and Foxall 2006), from our qualitative interviews, several personality variables, not previously addressed in this domain, appear to be related to why individuals stay in relationships. We identify two such factors—avoidance of conflict ( avoid ) and resistance to change ( resis ). As with procedural switching costs, these variables are constraint based and are not expected to connect with affective commitment
Hypothesis 1avoid : Avoidance of conflict is not associated with affective commitment.
Hypothesis 1resis : Resistance to change is not associated with affective commitment.
Individuals who possess a conflict-avoiding personality prefer not to assert themselves in order to preserve smooth relations with others (Schroeder 1965). They seek positive reinforcement and need to be seen as pleasant (Brock 1999), and thus, they often endure, rather than confront. Avoidance of conflict may be associated with feelings of obligation both to stay in a relationship due to a sense of obligation to the provider (normative commitment) and to a need to stay due to an inability to confront the provider (calculative commitment). These hypotheses are untested in the literature.
Hypothesis 2avoid : Avoidance of conflict is positively associated with normative commitment.
Hypothesis 3avoid : Avoidance of conflict is positively associated with calculative commitment.
Further, a similar trend exists in regard to resistance to change. This personality trait appears in the organizational behavior literature (e.g., Furst and Cable 2008), while marketers study it relative to resistance to innovation (Ellen, Bearden, and Sharma 1991). These individuals may feel locked into relationships due to a sense of obligation (normative commitment) and an inability to leave (calculative commitment). They feel that they need to stay to keep their lives simple and do not like changes to their daily routine (Kanner 1998) and are less likely to change where they shop (Brotherton 2001), producing the following untested hypotheses.
Hypothesis 2resis : Resistance to change is positively associated with normative commitment.
Hypothesis 3resis : Resistance to change is positively associated with calculative commitment.

sec.title: Affective commitment→voice
sec.p:
High affective commitment ( aff ) should drive consumers to provide PWOM about their service provider to friends and relatives, while reducing the likelihood of NWOM, because affective commitment reflects satisfaction and a positive attachment to the firm (see Table 2 for previous studies). While researchers have found the positive link, only two studies find the negative link (Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder 2007; Jones et al. 2007). Further, affective commitment should not directly link to silent endurance because silent endurance implies that an individual is not happy with their provider and is resisting voicing those concerns
Hypothesis 4aff : Affective commitment is positively associated with PWOM.
Hypothesis 5aff : Affective commitment is negatively associated with NWOM.
Hypothesis 6aff : Affective commitment is not associated with silent endurance.

sec.title: Normative commitment→voice
sec.p:
While Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder (2007) find a positive relationship between normative commitment ( norm ) and PWOM, we do not see any strong rationale to expect or predict such a relationship and feel it is not related to PWOM. On the other hand, it may be associated with silent endurance and NWOM. Normative commitment is obligation based and binds the customer to the service provider out of perceived obligation. Meyer and Allen (1997) contend that normative commitment develops through socialization when people internalize a set of norms concerning appropriate behavior. Subjective norms pressure individuals to conform (in this case, to stay; Fishbein and Ajzen 1980). This may be due to an interpersonal connection with the service provider, so s/he may be less likely to complain to the service provider but instead “just stays.” If s/he is unhappy, s/he may both suffer in silence and tell others about her unhappiness. Thus, in a social pressure-based relationship, s/he may feel as if s/he is a hostage, much as someone with high calculative commitment might feel. Kim, Ok, and Gwinner (2010) suggest that social pressure-based relationships may produce acquiescence or passive conformance. Further, the Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder (2007) finding that normative commitment is related to complaining (including the firm and others) is suggestive of this relationship, which has not been directly tested
Hypothesis 4norm : Normative commitment is not associated with PWOM.
Hypothesis 5norm : Normative commitment is positively associated with NWOM.
Hypothesis 6norm : Normative commitment is positively associated with silent endurance.

sec.title: Calculative commitment→voice
sec.p:
High calculative commitment ( calc ) should produce less PWOM, as well as more NWOM about their service provider to others. While several studies connect calculative commitment negatively to PWOM, one study connects it positively (see Table 2), the studies connecting it to NWOM have even more mixed results (Bloemer and Odekerken-Schröder 2007; Jones et al. 2007). These linkages are logical, noting that constraints reduce one’s perceived control, producing negative reactions and frustration (Averill 1973; Deci and Ryan 1985), producing fewer positive endorsements and more NWOM.
Hypothesis 4calc : Calculative commitment is negatively associated with PWOM.
Hypothesis 5calc : Calculative commitment is positively associated with NWOM.
Further, calculative commitment may also produce suffering in silence. Here individuals may have negative feelings about the relationship but they feel they cannot or should not voice them—thus, they may suffer in silence, rather than complaining to the company (thinking it would not help or wishing not to “make waves”). Consistent with this logic, Meyer, Allen, and Smith (1993) find a positive relationship between calculative commitment and neglect (i.e., passive withdrawal) in a study with working nurses.
Hypothesis 6calc : Calculative commitment is positively associated with silent endurance.

sec.title: Commitment interrelationships
sec.p: The relationship between the commitment components is somewhat controversial. Researchers often just treat them as correlated, especially in the management literature. However, Bansal, Irving, and Taylor (2004) and Meyer and Smith (2001) argue that affective commitment should influence normative commitment, noting that individuals who want to stay with a company may also feel a sense of obligation to do so. While Bansal, Irving, and Taylor (2004), in a study of customers of auto repair shops, did not find this link, Meyer and Smith (2001) in an employee-firm context did. Finally, Cater and Zabkar (2009) find this link with professional service providers, suggesting that past positive experiences with the service provider creates a psychological bond. This linkage may exist due to a desire to reciprocate to the party for which a positive relationship exists.

Additionally, Barksdale, Johnson, and Suh (1997) find a causal link between normative and calculative commitment in their study of patient-physician relationships in both fee-based and managed care relationships. The underlying rationale is that feeling a sense of obligation produces a need to stay, thus, linking obligations to feelings of constraint and lack of control (Averill 1973; Deci and Ryan 1985).
Hypothesis 7: Affective commitment is positively associated with normative commitment.
Hypothesis 8: Normative commitment is positively associated with calculative commitment.

sec.title: Silent endurance→WOM
sec.p:
When an individual “silently endures,” s/he may experience tension or frustration (regardless of why s/he is staying in the relationship). While their relationship overall with the firm may be positive, s/he may feel that s/he cannot complain (perhaps to shield the provider’s feelings), which may cause frustration. Negative affect tends to increase WOM activity (Westbrook 1987). Similarly, a frustrated customer who does not complain to the service provider may complain to others to release this frustration and may say fewer positive things. Jones et al. (2007) find that negative emotions (frustration, anger, and irritation) relate positively to NWOM. In addition, Hirschman’s (1970) exit, voice, and loyalty theory suggest that when customers are unable to exit a relationship, they seek ways to voice their displeasure, including NWOM (Geyskens et al. 1996). Singh (1990) argues that consumers are more likely to engage in NWOM when they believe their complaint efforts will be futile. These ideas produce the following untested predictions
Hypothesis 9: Silent endurance is negatively associated with PWOM.
Hypothesis 10: Silent endurance is positively associated with NWOM.

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: Our method included three stages. First, we conducted 22 depth interviews focusing on why individuals stay in relationships to identify the most prominent staying reasons. The researchers extensively and exhaustively analyzed these interviews by means of content analysis to develop the dimensions and subdimensions addressed here, with interjudge reliabilities in excess of 80%. Next, we conducted several pretests in which students served as the data collectors to assess our scales. Finally, we conducted the main study in which we drew an online panel using Zoomerang. This company maintains an online consumer panel of about 2.5 million consumers worldwide, including over 1 million consumers across the United States.

For the current study, Zoomerang randomly selected individuals for e-mail invitations based on the U.S. Census for age, gender, and household income. Individuals responding to the invitation provided responses about a service provider that they felt some personal sense of obligation to stay with (given that they could identify such a service provider). Given that affective commitment should affect normative commitment, which should affect calculative commitment, identifying relationships involving normative commitment (obligated relationships) ensured that the relationships examined represented “committed relationships.” We did not prespecify whether staying reasons were mostly positive or negative. Seven hundred and forty-two panel members responded to the survey invitation and identified such a relationship. Fifty-seven responses were dropped due to careless responding or to an inability to explain why they felt obligated to stay with the service provider, leaving a final sample of 685.

A wide variety of service industries appear in the responses, with the five most heavily represented being (1) doctor, health care provider, dentist (n = 176); (2) bank, mortgage lender, financial advisor, accountant (n = 125); (3) hairstylist, barber, manicurist (n = 90); (4) veterinarian (n = 63); and (5) car repair (n = 49).

The mean length of the relationship is 9.22 years (standard deviation = 9.28; range: 1-60 years). The sample is 45% male, with a range of age categories (37% are 19-35, 35% are 36-55, and 28% are 56 years or older). About 27% of the sample is single, 57% is married, 8% divorced, and the remaining 8% are either widowed or living with a partner. The sample is similar in composition to U.S. census data (U.S. Census Bureau 2009).

sec.title: Measures and Pretests
sec.p:
To measure our constructs, we drew our items from existing scales and adapted them as necessary, while we created a new scale for silent endurance, with items drawn from our qualitative interviews and from related literature and evaluated for content and face validity. The scales and instrument were thoroughly pretested to reduce the number of items needed in the final survey, to test the administration of the survey, and to minimize any clarity issues.
1

The final instrument contains items that measure the following 12 constructs: relational benefits (composed of special treatment benefits, social benefits, and confidence benefits), subjective norms, sunk costs, procedural switching costs, avoidance of conflict, resistance to change, affective commitment, normative commitment, calculative commitment, PWOM, NWOM, and silent endurance. The final scale items (after the final confirmatory factor analysis (CFA)) and their sources appear in the first several columns of Table 3 . All items are measured with 5-point Likert-type disagree-agree scales.

sec.title: Measurement Model
sec.p: In the measurement model, we model relational benefits as a second-order construct, comprised of special treatment benefits, social benefits, and confidence benefits. There were two reasons for this approach. First, these dimensions represent the underlying dimensions of relational benefits reported previously (Gwinner, Gremler, and Bitner 1998; Vazquez-Carrasco and Foxall 2006). Second, the relatively high correlations between the benefit subdimensions (ranging from .47 to .80) are indicative of a higher order construct (Anderson and Gerbing 1988).

All other variables are modeled as first-order constructs. We purified the measures with an initial confirmatory analysis in AMOS, dropping several items with low standardized factor loadings. The model was re-run. In this final model, all factor loadings are significant at p < .001 and all standardized factor loadings of the indicators are above .50. Table 3 presents the final loadings based on the purification model using Amos 6.0, along with reliability coefficients and AVEs (Anderson and Gerbing 1988; Fornell and Larcker 1981). We obtained a χ
2
of 2,368 with 968 degrees of freedom and a χ2/df ratio of 2.45, with ratios between 2 and 5, indicating an acceptable fit (Marsh and Hocevar 1985). Bollen’s (1989) incremental fit index (IFI) is .93, Bentler’s (1989) comparative fit index (CFI) is .92, with an RMSEA of .046, indicating an acceptable model fit. Further, composite reliabilities are strong, ranging from .73 to .93, while AVEs are .49 to .77, which are also reasonable.

Table 4 presents the correlations (below the diagonal), means, and standard deviations for the constructs. The means for the commitment types in this sample are instructive here. The mean for affective commitment is 3.35, while it is 2.93 for normative commitment and 2.50 for calculative commitment (with mean comparisons different at p < .001). Thus, although respondents answered the questions relative to relationships in which they felt some sense of obligation, affective commitment received the highest mean score. This is not surprising, given the importance of affective commitment (relative to the other commitments) to consumers in committed relationships, consistent with a long history of the importance of this construct in the literature.

sec.p: We assessed discriminant validity with the variance-extracted test (Fornell and Larcker 1981). All constructs achieve discriminant validity, except for two variables. The squared correlation for special treatment benefits and social benefits (.802 = .65) exceeds the AVE of social benefits (.56). Therefore, we tested the fit of a 3-factor second-order model (confidence, special treatment, and social benefits as separate subdimensions) against a 2-factor second-order model (where special treatment benefits and social benefits are combined into one dimension and confidence benefits is the second subdimension) to further assess the discriminant validity of these subdimensions. The results indicate that the 3-factor model fits the data better (χ2 for the 3-factor model = 84.72 with 17 df; χ2 for the 2-factor model = 197.9 with 19 df; Δ χ2 = 113.18 with 2 df; p < .05). Therefore, our relational benefits' higher order construct has three subdimensions, consistent with the literature and our expectations.

We investigate the threat of common method variance in two ways. First, we used the Harman 1-factor test. No single factor emerged from the analysis nor did a single general factor account for most of the variance in the variables, indicating that common method variance may not be an issue. The second method was the marker variable technique by Lindell and Whitney (2001), in which we chose a measure collected in the survey but unrelated to the constructs of the model. The marker variable used was attractiveness of alternatives. This measure was a 3-item scale adapted from Jones, Mothersbaugh, and Beatty (2000; α = .83). We then used the lowest positive correlation between this construct and the constructs in our model, which was .01 (i.e., the correlation between attractiveness of alternatives and avoidance of conflict). This correlation was used to create adjusted correlations between the constructs in the model, partialling out the effect of this marker-variable correlation from the uncorrected correlations in the model. The adjusted correlations appear above the diagonal in Table 4. Next, we assessed the significance levels of the adjusted correlations to determine whether there were any differences in significance levels between the uncorrected correlations and the adjusted correlations. All the uncorrected correlations that were significant before this adjustment were still significant after the adjustment. This implies that common method bias is not a concern in our model (Lindell and Whitney 2001).

sec.title: Hypotheses Testing
sec.p:
For the structural model (using Amos 6.0), aggregate measures were created and error terms for the constructs were set, using procedures put forth by Jöreskog and Sorbom (1993). To mitigate concerns of the potential effect of other variables not identified in our model, we regressed all items in our model on several covariates and then we obtained the residuals (i.e., the items with covariate effects parceled out). We then used these residuals to test our hypothesized model in AMOS (see Luo and Bhattacharya (2006) for a similar approach). The covariates include the following: industry type based on Lovelock’s (1983) classification scheme
2
, the frequency of contact the respondent had with the service provider (responses ranged from once a week to less than once a year); the length of time in the relationship (indicated by months or years in the relationship); and whether or not a contract existed (yes/no response). These covariates capture factors relative to the type of company and nature of the relationship between the provider and respondent.

The results of the initial structural model indicated a poor fitting model. (Bentler and Bonett's (1980) normed fit index (NFI) = .92, CFI = .92 and the χ2/df ratio =12.46; (χ2 = 224.34 with 18 df). Our initial model had all staying reasons going through the commitment components to all of the voice elements; however, the modification indices indicated five potential direct paths from staying reasons to voice elements. In examining these paths, we felt that they could be supported theoretically, thus, we added them to our final model. We acknowledge that we did not anticipate that commitment would fully mediate all staying reasons but did not attempt to model the potential direct effects for the sake of parsimony. These added paths and their results appear at the bottom of Table 5 . The results from this revised structural model indicate an adequate fit (NFI = .98, CFI = .99 and the χ2/df ratio =3.68; χ2 = 47.93 with 13 df). The model explains 56% of the variance in affective commitment, 44% of the variance in normative commitment, 55% of the variance in calculative commitment, 56% in PWOM, 36% in NWOM, and 53% in silent endurance. sec.p: The analysis supports two of the three relational benefit hypotheses, that is, relational benefits are positively associated with affective commitment (Hypothesis 1ben: β =.40, t = 10.68) and negatively associated with calculative commitment (Hypothesis 3ben: β = −.36, t = −9.05). Further, two of the three subjective norms hypotheses are supported by the analysis, with subjective norms positively associated with affective commitment (Hypothesis 1snorm: β = .24, t = 6.75) and normative commitment (Hypothesis 2snorm: β = .22, t = 5.30) but not with calculative commitment (Hypothesis 3snorm: β = .05, t = 1.17). Also, sunk costs are associated with affective and calculative commitment (Hypothesis 1sunk: β = .37, t = 9.81; Hypothesis 3sunk: β = .11, t = 2.71) but not with normative commitment (Hypothesis 2sunk: β = .02, t = .48).

Procedural switching costs are associated with normative and calculative commitments, as expected (Hypothesis 2pswitch: β = .20, t = 5.04; Hypothesis 3pswitch: β = .15, t = 4.99, respectively) and also unexpectedly, and negatively, with affective commitment (Hypothesis 1pswitch: β = −.07, t = −2.05). The analysis supports the expected relationship between avoidance of conflict and normative commitment (Hypothesis 2avoid: β = .17, t = 4.87), but instead of finding a positive relationship with calculative commitment we found a low, but significantly positive, relationship with affective commitment, thus failing to support Hypothesis 1avoid or Hypothesis 3avoid. The analysis supports all resistance to change hypotheses, on the other hand. It is positively related to normative and calculative commitments (Hypothesis 2resis: β = .11, t = 2.80; Hypothesis 3resis: β = .08, t = 2.08, respectively) but not related to affective commitment (Hypothesis 1resis: β = .04, t = 1.10).

While affective commitment relates positively to PWOM as expected and is not associated with silent endurance, its effect on NWOM was not supported by the analysis (Hypothesis 4aff: β = .19, t = 4.09; Hypothesis 5aff: β = −.04, t = −.93; Hypothesis 6aff: β = −.01, t = −.11, respectively). As expected, normative commitment did not relate to PWOM (Hypotheis 4norm: β = −.03, t = −.55), but it did negatively influence NWOM and did not influence silent endurance, in contradiction to the hypotheses (Hypothesis 5norm: β = −.12, t = −2.04; Hypothesis 6norm: β = .02, t =.26, respectively). In support of all three calculative commitment hypotheses, it related negatively to PWOM and positively to NWOM and silent endurance (Hypothesis 4cal: β = −.11, t = −2.01; Hypothesis 5cal: β = .22, t = −3.44; Hypothesis 6cal: β =.46, t = −8.87, respectively). Affective commitment predictably influences normative commitment, while normative influences calculative, as expected (Hypothesis 7: β = .38, t = 6.88; Hypothesis 8: β = .53, t = 12.02, respectively). Finally, silent endurance influences PWOM negatively and NWOM positively, as expected (Hypothesis 9: β = −.21, t = −4.53; Hypothesis 10: β = .48, t = 9.53, respectively).

sec.title: Model Comparison
sec.p: It is important in using structural equation modeling to compare rival models (Bollen and Long 1992). Our conceptual model in Figure 1 indicates that our antecedent variables go through commitment to influence voice. As noted in the results section, we added five direct paths from reasons to voice elements to improve the fit of the model. However, this revised model still suggests that commitment mediates many of the effects between reasons and voice. We compare this model against a direct effects model where all reasons and the three commitment components directly influence voice. The paths between the commitment variables (affective to normative; normative to calculative) remained and the paths between our voice elements remained (silent to PWOM; silent to NWOM) in this direct effects model. The fit of the direct effects model is: χ2 = 347.86; df = 13; p <.01, χ2/df = 26.76, CFI = .88, akaike information criteria (ACI) = 477.86, NFI = .88, standardized root mean square residual (SRMR) = .12, root mean square error approximation (RMSEA) = .19. We compare this new model against our hypothesized model in Table 5. Our model in Table 5 is clearly superior based on the chi-square estimate (47.93 vs. 347.86); chi-square/df ratio (3.68 vs. 26.76), AIC (177.94 vs. 477.86) and all fit measures (e.g., NFI: .98 vs. .88; RMSEA: .06 vs. .19).

sec.title: Discussion and Theoretical Implications
sec.p: Based on both qualitative and quantitative research, the current research addresses important staying reasons as antecedents to the three commitment components, as well as the commitment components' effects on three important elements of voice. This is the first fully comprehensive effort in the literature to link this full set of variables together and the explained variance of the commitment and voice variables is reasonable, ranging from .36 to .56. Additionally, although we assess all linkages, we are most interested in those relationships not yet tested nor clearly established (i.e., those highlighted in Tables 1 and 2), thereby contributing to some important gaps in our knowledge about these relationships. While the analysis does not support all links, a number of important and understudied relationships find support.

sec.title: Staying Reasons→Commitment Findings
sec.p: We first linked staying reasons to the three commitment components. We predicted 18 relationships, with 12 of these supported by our analyses (with 7 of these supported relationships previously untested or unclear). Beyond the expected link of relational benefits to affective commitment, we also found strong support for a less studied link—the negative relationship between relational benefits and calculative commitment. This finding suggests the importance of relational benefits on two of the three commitments. The negative relationship between relational benefits and calculative commitment suggests that relational benefits reduce a consumer’s feelings of being a hostage in a relationship and indicates how differently the commitments operate. On the other hand, we wondered whether the lack of relationship between relational benefits and normative commitment was due to our combining the benefits together and wondered specifically whether social benefits positively relate to normative commitment if examined alone. However, this was not the case (social benefit: β = .06, t = 1.31), suggesting that combining benefits did not obfuscate our findings.

With regard to subjective norms, our results show that when customers perceive that important others think they should stay, they often want to stay and become personally committed (affective commitment). They also feel that they should stay (normative commitment). This influence may be due to an internalization of the idea or identifying with the influencing party. Our qualitative results contain many examples of individuals who said they stay with a service provider because their friends or family use the provider, recommended the provider, or encouraged them to stay. Interestingly, the subjective norms to affective commitment link has received little attention in the literature, while the lack of effect of subjective norms on calculative commitment suggests that their effects work through a consumer’s affective and normative commitment, rather than directly on calculative commitment.

With regard to sunk costs, our analysis supports their expected effect on calculative commitment, but additionally they also positively affect affective commitment, as suspected. This effect could be due to an escalation of commitment. On the other hand, sunk costs do not directly affect normative commitment but seem to operate through the other types of commitment. The importance of sunk costs to affective commitment is intriguing since they have primarily been associated with calculative commitment. Gwinner, Gremler, and Bitner (1998), Colgate et al. (2007), and Paul et al. (2009) identify the importance of history in staying, which is close to the idea of sunk costs. However, this idea drops out in the quantitative phase of Gwinner, Gremler, and Bitner’s study and does not appear in Colgate’s final staying factors. Paul et al. (2009) relate history to benefits and higher level motivational values but not to commitment.

With both relational benefits and sunk costs drawing support from Blau’s (1964) social exchange theory and its underlying idea of reciprocity, this research reinforces the importance of this theory in this domain. Individuals feel indebted to service providers who have given to them or who have gone out of the way for them in the past and/or to whom the customers have expended (invested) much effort and time in the past. This phenomenon also suggests the power of gratitude addressed by Palmatier et al. 2009.

In regard to procedural switching costs, the analysis supports their expected effects on calculative commitment, as well as on normative commitment, which was untested. We argue that this latter effect may be due to the consumer’s rationalization and escalation of commitment to the party involved. We were expecting a null relationship between procedural switching costs and affective commitment, but a slightly (but significant) negative relationship between the two was obtained, suggesting that these perceived costs (which cause a consumer to feel locked into a company) can reduce positive affect toward the company.

Given that no previous study has examined the personality variables studied here relative to the commitments, this area is a virgin territory, and four of our six hypotheses find support. Both avoidance of conflict and resistance to change positively relate to normative commitment, suggesting the strong effect of personality on commitment due to social pressure or obligation. Oddly, however, the relationship between avoidance and affective commitment was not neutral, but slightly positive (perhaps also due an escalation of commitment and rationalization), while the expected effect of avoidance on calculative commitment did not materialize. The analysis supports all of the resistance to change hypotheses, including the previously untested relationship of resistance to change tending to lock the consumer in (i.e., positively associated with calculative commitment). Thus, the findings suggest a weak but relevant impact of personality variables on commitment. Additionally, the personality variables have some direct positive effects on silent endurance, which we did not initially model (see Table 5).

sec.title: Commitment and Voice Findings
sec.p: The analysis generally supports the commitment components and voice elements hypotheses, with 10 of 13 hypotheses supported (with four supported hypotheses previously untested or receiving minimal support in the past). While the analyses support the expected effects of affective commitment and calculative commitment on PWOM, we had expected normative commitment to affect silent endurance and NWOM positively, but instead it negatively affected NWOM and did not affect silent endurance. This suggests that higher normative commitment reduces WOM to others, while having no influence on silent endurance. Given a positive link between subjective norms and silent endurance in the final model, subjective norms seems to capture the impact of other’s influence on not voicing better than normative commitment does.

Further, the findings relative to calculative commitment are consistent with expectations and past findings, although past findings are few. These findings show the strength of the negative influence of calculative commitment on voice, while normative commitment has minimal direct effects and affective commitment only affects PWOM. However, normative commitment still has some significant total effects on voice (normative → PWOM: β = −.141, t = 3.36; normative → silent: β = .259, t = 4.98; normative → NWOM: β = .120, t = 3.08). These findings interestingly imply a negative impact of normative commitment on voice.

Perhaps the most powerful (and previously unexplored) findings here are the strong relationships between silent endurance and PWOM and NWOM. The relationship between silence and NWOM has only been hinted at in the past conceptually (e.g., Hirschman 1970) and in one empirical study (Jones et al. 2007). Thus, consumers who feel they cannot complain to their service providers express their unhappiness to others and do not say positive things about the firm.

Finally, the interconnections between commitments find support here, with affective commitment influencing normative commitment, which influences calculative commitment. In fact, Meyer and Parfyonova (2010) recently suggested that normative commitment has two faces. Under its positive face, affective and normative commitments are strongly associated; while under its negative face, it is more strongly associated with calculative commitment. This idea may explain why our analysis did not support several hypotheses relative to normative commitment, suggesting the need to understand normative commitment’s connection to other commitments better.

sec.title: Managerial Implications
sec.p: Discretionary behaviors, such as voice, are strongly associated with an individual’s commitment to a firm. However, clearly, different forms of commitment affect voice differently. Firms should do everything possible to avoid silent endurance in their customers. This silence produces active WOM to others, much of which is not positive. Thus, firms need to make communicating with them easy and painless for their customers. Customers should feel they can give honest, anonymous feedback to the firm, and employees need training in how to encourage customers to “open up.” Suggestion boxes, e-mails, or blogs should be encouraged.

Further, firms need to understand their customers. Customers who stay because they do not want a conflict or do not want to change are of particular concern. Firms need creative solutions—such as offering individuals opportunities to switch to another person in the operation that they may like better, without having to confront their former service provider. These customers could be encouraged to work with multiple employees within the same firm, to avoid that lock in feeling with a particular service employee.

Additionally, given the strong negative relationship between relational benefits and calculative commitment, silent endurance, and less PWOM, firms should emphasize and measure relational benefits. Burnham, Frels, and Mahajan (2003, p. 109) state “firms appear to be stuck in a ‘satisfaction trap,’ a myopic belief that customer satisfaction and service quality are the only tools for managing customer retention.” Thus, a clear alternative candidate is relational benefits.

With subjective norms, firms can emphasize the importance of the opinions of others and who is best and most trustworthy at providing those opinions than friends and family. Also, firms can focus on social networks or community clubs as ways to establish personal connections. However, firms should do so cautiously, given that customers should not feel both obligated and unhappy (i.e., the high normative commitment–calculative commitment condition). Also, the positive link noted between subjective norms and silent endurance suggests that customers may be less willing to complain to service providers that they are staying with due to social pressure. Thus, firms need to ensure that these individuals be able to anonymously complain or voice their concerns.

While sunk costs have some impact on calculative commitment, they also strongly influence affective commitment. Thus, firms may want to emphasize the importance of the customer’s past history with the firm. However, this should be done cautiously, given that the total net effect of sunk costs on silent endurance is positive (β = .091, t = 2.94), suggesting that past investments or history may cause a customer to be less willing to voice concerns and suggestions for improvement to the firm.

Finally, customers need to feel that they are not locked in (high calculative commitment)—and that they can move, either to a different firm or different employee in the same firm because of calculative commitment’s negative effects on voice. Over time, their frustration can turn negative (beyond silent endurance), which can take many forms, from exiting the firm to retaliating against it.

Thus, our research clearly shows that different forms of commitment have different effects on voice outcomes. Firms wishing to build loyal customer advocates need to recognize that calculative commitment may have short-term beneficial effects but can be detrimental in the long term, given its potential harm on positive customer relations (less PWOM, more NWOM, and more silent endurance). Further, feelings of being unable to “voice” to the service provider may chip away at the relationship with the firm, with these impressions passed on to others, as well.

sec.title: Limitations and Future Research
sec.p: Although this study provides new insights into the factors (both positive and negative) that keep customers in service relationships, there are limitations to consider. For example, although the sample exhibited broad representation in a number of demographic categories, it is not a random sample. Therefore, future research should investigate the variables studied here across other populations. Additionally, although real behavioral data would be difficult to obtain in regard to these variables, there is always a concern with using self-report data only.

Further, while individuals talked about a wide range of contexts, contextual effects are always a concern. Although we found no contextual findings, generalizability is always a concern, especially noting that other studies have found some contextual effects. Another concern is our initial screening question, which focused on individuals in obligation-oriented relationships. Future research should expand on the type of relationships solicited from respondents. Also, many routes to commitment and their interrelationships should be explored. Future studies should also specify the target of the commitment (Jones, Taylor, and Bansal 2008).

Future studies should break relational benefits out to ascertain their unique effects. Further, the adapted items used for the special treatment scale were not true to the original scale items, which addressed a comparison between service providers, which may have affected the results. Additionally, the exploration of normative commitment vis-à-vis other commitments offers great opportunities, as it is the most misunderstood commitment type. Studying commitment profiles should prove useful in understanding the two faces of normative commitment (Meyer and Parfyonova 2010).

Thus, in conclusion, there are many opportunities for research in this area. Besides the above-mentioned research topics, the following areas are ripe for study: the effects of interactions between staying reasons on commitment; staying reason profiles of committed consumers (based on different commitment profiles as well); the emotions of consumers in committed relationships that most likely drive commitment and voice at a deeper psychological level; the effects of environmental, partner, interaction factors on staying reasons and commitment (cf. Bendapudi and Berry 1997); the effects of the personality variables studied here or other personality variables on voice, especially on silent endurance (given that several links were revealed in the revised model); and finally, the breaking point of consumers in regard to when they decide to exit a relationship (cf. Coulter and Ligas 2000). Additionally, meta-analyses of these topics would be useful.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, in this article we examine the staying reason antecedents of commitment components, developed from our qualitative interviews, as well as several voice elements here. While this research domain has received considerable attention in the past, we provide and study a comprehensive framework of these relationships, focusing attention on some less tested links. We encourage others to continue to pursue this research domain.

Students in several upper level undergraduate marketing classes at two southeastern universities earned extra credit by recruiting nonstudent participants for the survey. Eight hundred and ninety respondents participated in the pretest survey. Items were subjected to exploratory and confirmatory factor analyses to reduce the item pool. We compared our results to a model where we did not control for the four covariates listed earlier. Three small changes occurred when we did not include these covariates. In all three cases relationships that were close to .05 significance levels failed to reach the .05 level (proc. switching costs → affective; calculative → PWOM) or vice versa (resistance to change → affective). These changes were very small, thus mitigating concerns as to the potential influence of these covariates or other covariates not in our model. We also tested to see whether there were industry differences in this model, given some past results suggesting differences (Singh 1990). The difference in χ2 (72.51 with 74 df) is not significant (p = .527), indicating that the unconstrained model does not fit our data better than the constrained model, hence the structural paths across the industries are equivalent.
